abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, and unsatisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower, although
            institutional development impacts were modest. Lessons
            convey that while the project estimated the risk of not
            continuing the reforms as "moderate", it provided
            relatively little technical and financial support for
            pursuing the reforms, in fact, very few of the legal and
            regulatory texts cited in the Appraisal Report ever became
            operational, and, of particular importance was the
            insufficient project preparation to follow-up on the PNAC -
            Pharmacie Nationale Approvisionnement des Comores - and to
            develop modalities for ensuring services for the poor. The
            risk should probably have been considered
            "substantial" at minimum, and appropriate measures
            should have been included, to ensure continued support and
            monitoring during implementation. Further lessons suggest
            that Project restructuring should be considered,
            particularly after long delays in implementation; regional
            specificities, even in small countries, must be taken into
            account during project preparation and implementation; where
            capacity for policy analysis and program decision-making is
            inadequate, project design and implementation must develop a
            consensus for program implementation.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project development objective of the
            Health Project for the Comoros is to reduce mortality from
            common diseases by ensuring a better use of health
            facilities for the delivery of quality health care, and by
            organizing mosquito control activities to reduce the
            incidence of malaria. There are three components: 1)
            rehabilitating and equipping selected health facilities to
            facilitate the delivery of good quality health care to the
            population, which will also have a direct favorable impact
            on cost recovery by those facilities; 2) controlling malaria
            by improving the case management at all levels of the health
            service, educating the population for a better use of
            services and to improve case management at home, and
            preventive activities including mosquito control to reduce
            the incidence of the disease; and 3) institutional
            strengthening to facilitate and support the increased use of
            quality care by the population and to further implement
            health sector reforms, including a) training the staff of
            the public health and population ministry (MOH) and the
            health facilities staff in the delivery of quality health
            care, management, and accounting; b) studies to develop
            alternative mechanisms for health financing; and c)
            technical assistance, logistical support, and equipment for
            MOH's central and regional directorates and for PNAC
            (the agency in charge of marketing drugs).
